questions.text: Which of the following is false about peptic ulceration?

options.label: A
options.text: Gastric ulcerations are more common than duodenal ulcers

options.label: B
options.text: Gastric ulcer may become malignant and an ulcerated gastric cancer may mimic a benign ulcer.

options.label: D
options.text: H. Pylori eradication therapy is the mainstay of treatment

questions.correct_answer: A. Gastric ulcerations are more common than duodenal ulcers
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastric ulcerations are more common than duodenal ulcers Peptic ulceration: Most peptic ulcers are caused by pylori or NSAIDs and changes in epidemiology mirror changes in these principal aetiological factors Duodenal ulcers are more common than gastric ulcers, but the symptoms are indistinguishable Gastric ulcers may become malignant and an ulcerated gastric cancer may mimic a benign ulcer Gastric antisecretory agents and H. pylori eradication therapy are the mainstays of treatment, and elective surgery is very rarely performed The long-term complications of peptic ulcer surgery may be difficult to treat The common complications of peptic ulcers are perforation, bleeding, and stenosis The treatment of perforated peptic ulcers is primarily surgical, although some patients may be managed conservatively.

Highyeild:

Peptic ulcers are primarily caused by pylori infection or NSAID use . Changes in the prevalence of these factors affect the epidemiology of peptic ulceration. Duodenal ulcers are more common than gastric ulcers, but both can present with similar symptoms. Gastric ulcers can be malignant and may resemble benign ulcers. Treatment options include gastric antisecretory agents and H. pylori eradication therapy, with elective surgery being a rare option.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: B, C, & D. All are true statements.

Extraedge:

Long-term complications from peptic ulcer surgery can be difficult to manage. Complications of peptic ulcers include perforation, bleeding, and stenosis. Treatment for a perforated peptic ulcer typically involves surgery, although some patients may be managed conservatively.

questions.text: False about Late dumping are all Except:

options.label: C
options.text: Occurs on the second hour after a meal

questions.correct_answer: C. Occurs on the second hour after a meal
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Occurs on the second hour after a meal Early Dumping: Incidence 5–10% Relation to meals: Almost immediate Duration of attack 30–40 minutes. Relief: Lying down Aggravated by More food Precipitating factor Food, especially carbohydrate-rich and wet Major symptoms: Epigastric fullness, sweating, lightheadedness, tachycardia, colic, and sometimes diarrhea Late dumping: Incidence 5% Relation to meals: Second hour after a meal Duration of attack 30–40 minutes. Relief: Food Aggravated by Exercise Precipitating factor Food, especially carbohydrate-rich and wet Major symptoms: Tremor, faintness, prostration.

Highyeild:

Dumping syndrome refers to symptoms that occur after a meal in patients who have had gastric surgery or vagotomy. Although the symptoms of early and late dumping are similar, their underlying causes are different. Early dumping is characterized by abdominal and vasomotor symptoms, which occur due to rapid gastric emptying leading to a high osmotic load in the small bowe This results in the sequestration of fluid from the circulation into the gastrointestinal tract, leading to the symptoms. Small, regular meals based on fat and protein, and avoiding fluids with high carbohydrate content are the principal treatment. Octreotide may be useful in some individuals. Late dumping , is due to reactive hypoglycemia , which occurs when the carbohydrate load in the small bowel causes a rise in plasma glucose, leading to secondary hypoglycemia due to an increase in insulin levels. The treatment is similar to that for early dumping, and octreotide is effective in dealing with this problem. Revisional surgery may be occasionally required in some patients. Antrectomy with Roux-en-Y reconstruction is often effective for patients with late dumping syndrome following gastrectomy, although the procedure is of greater magnitude.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, B, & D . All other options are true statements.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) Largely Malabsorptive, Mildly Restrictive Biliopancreatic diversion (BPD) Duodenal switch (DS)

Highyeild:

BPD is a weight loss surgery associated with greater weight loss than other procedures. BPD is also associated with a higher rate of nutritional complications. Th e primary mechanism of action for BPD is the malabsorption of calories. BPD/DS is the most commonly performed version of BPD. BPD/DS involves a sleeve gastrectomy, division of the duodenum, division of the ileum with a linear stapler, and the creation of a common channel and an alimentary channel. BPD/DS is increasingly considered a definitive procedure, especially after significant weight regains following sleeve gastrectomy.

A high-protein diet, regular vitamin and mineral supplements, lifelong monitoring, and patient commitment are essential postoperatively to prevent malnutrition. BPD/DS procedures are only offered by a few centers.

questions.text: Increased Gastric acid secretion occurs in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type 3 gastric ulcer The modified Johnson anatomic classification system for gastric ulcers (i.e., types I through V) was developed before the modern understanding that most ulcers are the consequence of H. pylori infection or NSAID usage

Highyeild:

The Johnson anatomic classification system for gastric ulcers was developed before the understanding that most ulcers are caused by H. pylori infection or NSAID use, but it is still relevant for surgical treatment of complications. Gastric ulcers can occur anywhere in the stomach but usually appear on the lesser curvature near the incisura. Type I gastric ulcers ( 60 % of ulcers) are not associated with excessive acid secretion and can occur with low to normal acid output. Type II gastric ulcers ( 15% ) are located in the body of the stomach and are associated with excess acid secretion and usually occur in combination with a duodenal ulcer. Type III gastric ulcers ( 20 %) are pre-pyloric ulcers and behave similarly to duodenal ulcers and are associated with the hypersecretion of gastric acid. Type IV gastric ulcers (less than 10% ) occur high on the lesser curvature, near the GE junction, and are not associated with excessive acid secretion. Type V gastric ulcers can occur at any location and are associated with long-term NSAID use. Gastric ulcers rarely occur before the age of 40 , and the peak incidence occurs in individuals 55 to 65 years old. Clinical conditions that may predispose gastric ulceration include chronic alcohol intake, smoking, long-term corticosteroid therapy, infection, and intra-arterial therapy. Acid is essential to producing a gastric ulcer, but the total secretory output is less important. Gastric ulcers can cause pain, bleeding, and obstruction and can perforate. Differentiating between benign ulcers and gastric carcinoma can be challenging. Treatment of gastric ulceration involves acid suppression and H. pylori eradication, and ruling out malignancy is critical. Intractable nonhealing ulcers are becoming less common, and patients with nonhealing gastric ulcers in the H. pylori era should be evaluated for underlying malignancy.

III – Pre-pyloric, Acid level is Increased IV - High on lesser curve, Acid level is Normal V – Anywhere, the Acid level is Normal, NSAID-induced Option: D. All of the above cannot be the answer.

questions.text: Apple peel or Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap is what type of jejunoileal atresia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type IIIb Type IIIb, an apple peel or Christmas tree deformity with a large mesenteric gap, in which the distal bowel receives a retrograde blood supply from the ileocolic or right colic artery. This tenuous blood supply has implications for anastomotic failures and the potential for ischemic necrosis from volvulus. Thus, many of these infants with this type of atresia are born with reduced intestinal length. Jejunoileal atresia is the most common GI atresia; it occurs in 1 in 2000 live births . It is thought to result from an intrauterine mesenteric vascular accident. Atresias are slightly more common in the jejunum than in the ileum. Jejunoileal atresias are classified as type I, a mucosal web or diaphragm;

Highyeild:

Jejunoileal atresia is the most common GI atresia, occurring in 1 in 2000 live births. It is believed to result from an intrauterine mesenteric vascular accident. Infants present with bilious emesis, abdominal distention, and failure to pass meconium. Clinical presentation varies by the location of the atretic obstruction. In proximal atresia, significant bilious emesis occurs. In distal atresias, abdominal distention with multiple dilated bowel loops is more common. A contrast enema study is often unnecessary to make the diagnosis of jejunoileal atresia. Multiple intestinal atresias can occur in 10%-15% of cases. Jejunoileal atresia is generally not associated with other anomalies except cystic fibrosis (CF) in approximately 10% of patients. Jejunoileal atresias are classified into five types : type I, type II, type IIIa, type IIIb, and type IV. Infants are managed for neonatal bowel obstruction, with the placement of an orogastric tube and IV fluid resuscitation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Type II, with an atretic cord between two blind ends of the bowel with intact mesentery; Option: B. Type IIIa, a complete separation of the blind ends of the bowel by a V-shaped mesenteric gap; Option: D. In type IV, there are multiple atresias, with a string of sausage appearance.

Extraedge:

At operation, the main objective is to establish intestinal continuity, while preserving as much intestinal length as possible. In cases of multiple atresias, multiple anastomoses over an endoluminal stent may be necessary. If the proximal intestine is significantly dilated, a tapering enteroplasty of the dilated segment should be considered. The overall survival for infants with jejunoileal atresia is more than 90%.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient came with a bleeding peptic ulcer, endoscopy is done. Which of the following findings on endoscopy predicts the lowest rate of rebleed?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nonbleeding vessel Bleeding peptic ulcer is mostly from the posterior surface of the lesion. Forrest classification is used to grade the risk of rebleeding in peptic ulcers. Forest classification The Forrest classification for endoscopic findings and rebleeding risks in peptic ulcer disease. CLASSIFICATION REBLEEDING RISK Grade la Active, pulsatile bleeding High Grade lb Active, nonpulsatile bleeding High Grade lla Nonbleeding visible vessel High Grade IIb Adherent clot Intermediate Grade llc Ulcer with black spot Low Grade III Clean, nonbleeding ulcer bed Low

Highyeild:

The Forrest classification is used to assess the risk of re-bleeding based on endoscopic findings in patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB). The classification groups patients into the high, intermediate, and low risk of re-bleeding . Endoscopic therapy is recommended for ulcers with active bleeding or a visible ulcer (Forrest I-IIa), while ulcers with a clean base or black spot secondary to hematoma deposition (Forrest IIc-III) do not require endoscopic treatment and are managed medically. If endoscopic intervention is needed, approximately 25% of patients undergoing EGD for UGIB will require it. If endoscopic therapy is unsuccessful, angiography is recommended, and surgery is the next step if angiography fails or is not available. All patients with confirmed peptic ulcer bleed should receive PPI therapy. Preendoscopic high-dose IV PPI therapy is associated with a decreased frequency of high-risk findings on endoscopy (Forrest Ia-IIa) and reduces the need for endoscopic intervention. Continuing PPI therapy post-endoscopy also reduces the risk of further bleeding, the need for surgery, and mortality. Eradication of H. pylori infection, if present, results in less re-bleeding, and confirmation of successful therapy should be done

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Adherent clot: Intermediate rebleeding risk Option: B. Flat pigmented spot: low rebleeding risk Option: C. clean base ulcer: low rebleeding risk

questions.text: The lowest recurrence of peptic ulcer is associated with?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vagotomy +Antrectomy The indications for surgery in PUD are (in order of decreasing frequency) perforation, obstruction, and bleeding. Recurrence rates are lowest with vagotomy + antrectomy but morbidity highest with the latter procedure, while the opposite is true for HSV.

Highyeild:

Most emergent ulcer surgeries involve a simple patch or oversewing of a perforated or bleeding ulcer. Vagotomy may improve outcomes and should be considered in stable, low-risk patients. Many randomized clinical trials evaluating elective operation for PUD may not be relevant to most patients today, as they were done in the pre-PPI, pre-Helicobacter, and pre-NSAID eras and focused on intractable disease. Traditionally, three basic operations were used to treat peptic ulcers : parietal cell vagotomy (also known as highly selective vagotomy or proximal gastric vagotomy) , vagotomy and drainage, and vagotomy and distal gastrectomy. Recurrence rates are lowes t but morbidity highest with vagotomy and distal gastrectomy, while the opposite is true for highly selective vagotomy. While elective highly selective vagotomy has largely been supplanted by long-term PPI treatment, it may still be useful for non-compliant, intolerant, or unable-to-afford medical treatment patients. Highly selective vagotomy may not perform as well historically for type II and type III gastric ulcers.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, B, & D. Are a/w increased risk of recurrence Note: Hsv has the highest rate of recurrence but the least morbidity.

questions.text: All are true about Dieulafoy's lesion except:

options.label: A
options.text: Angiographic embolization is the first line of treatment

options.label: C
options.text: Pulsation of the artery causes ulceration

questions.correct_answer: A. Angiographic embolization is the first line of treatment
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Angiographic embolization is the first line of treatment Dieulafoy lesion: Dieulafoy lesions are vascular malformations found primarily along the lesser curve of the stomach within 6 cm of the gastroesophageal junction , although they can occur elsewhere in the GI tract. They represent the rupture of unusually large vessels (1 to 3 mm) found in the gastric submucosa. Erosion of the gastric mucosa overlying these vessels leads to hemorrhage. The mucosal defect is usually small (2 to 5 mm) and may be difficult to identify. Given the large size of the underlying artery, bleeding from a Dieulafoy lesion can be massive. Initial attempts at endoscopic control are often successful. The application of thermal or sclerosant therapy is effective in 80%. to 100% of cases. In cases that fail endoscopic therapy, angiographic coil embolization can be successful. If these approaches are unsuccessful, surgical intervention may be necessary; because of difficulties in visualization and palpation of these lesions, prior endoscopic tattooing can facilitate the procedure. A gastrostomy is performed, and attempts are made at identifying the bleeding source. The lesion can then be oversewn. In cases in which the bleeding point is not identified, a partial gastrectomy may be necessary.

Highyeild:

A Dieulafoy lesion is a malformation found in the gastric arterial-venous system with a unique histological appearance. It can cause severe upper gastrointestinal bleeding that is difficult to manage. The lesion is usually covered by normal mucosa and may not be visible when not bleeding. Profuse bleeding from an area of normal mucosa indicates the cause of bleeding is the Dieulafoy lesion. Endoscopic identification of the lesion can be done, and bleeding can be stopped by sclerosant injection or endoscopic clip application. Local excision is the only necessary treatment if the lesion is identified during surgery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: B, C, & D. All other options are true statements.

Extraedge:

Dieulafoy lesions are relatively rare , accounting for only 1-2% of cases of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. The exact cause of Dieulafoy lesions is unknown , but they are thought to be congenital or acquired. Patients with a Dieulafoy lesion may experience symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and dizziness in addition to bleeding. Endoscopic ultrasound can be used to detect Dieulafoy lesions that may be missed during standard endoscopy. Dieulafoy lesions can occur in other areas of the body, including the colon and the bronchus .

questions.text: Decubitus ulcer is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trophic ulcer Decubitus ulcer or Pressure ulcer is a trophic ulcer. Excessive pressure causes capillary collapse and impedes the delivery of nutrients to body tissues.

Highyeild:

Decubitus ulcer, also known as a pressure ulcer, is a type of skin and tissue injury caused by prolonged pressure on the skin This pressure reduces blood flow and damages the skin and underlying tissue. Decubitus ulcers most commonly occur in bony areas where there is less tissue between the bone and skin, such as the heels, hips, and tailbone.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented with recurrent abdominal pain, fever, and melena. The patient's abdomen was soft, with slight tenderness in the upper region. The laboratory results showed anemia and hypoproteinemia. The patient received emergency surgery due to shock as a result of a massive hemorrhage of the GI tract. Which of the following is the most common cause of upper GI bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Duodenal ulcer 60% of the upper GI bleeding is attributed to ulcers, out of which 33% is attributed to duodenal ulcers and hence, is the most common cause of upper GI bleed.

Highyeild:

Demographic changes have occurred in patients with duodenal ulceration in the West. The use of gastric antisecretory agents and pylori eradication therap y for dyspepsia has contributed to these changes. The peak incidence of duodenal ulceration is now in an older age group, and the difference in gender is less marked. These changes reflect the changes in the epidemiology of pylori infection. Duodenal ulcers are most commonly found in the first part of the duodenum. Chronic ulcers can lead to fibrosis and deformities such as pyloric stenosis . Healing may leave a residual scar in the mucosa. Multiple ulcers may be present, known as "kissing ulcers."

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. 6% of the upper GI bleeding is attributed to oesophageal ulcers. Option: B. 21% of the upper GI bleeding is attributed to gastric ulcers. Option: D. 4% of the upper GI bleeding is attributed to oesophageal varices.

Extraedge:

Anterior ulcers tend to perforate , while posterior ulcers tend to bleed. The entire duodenal cap may be ulcerated and devoid of mucosa in rare cases. Giant duodenal ulcers are usually benign. Microscopically, the base of the ulcer is covered with granulation tissue . Pathological interpretations of healing ulcers must be careful, as epithelial down growth can be misinterpreted as an invasion.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man known to be suffering from diabetes and previous deep venous thrombosis was admitted to the hospital due to melaena. Besides tachycardia, the patient had a BP of 154/90 mm Hg and a hemoglobin level of 6.4 mmol/L. The patient suddenly became hypotensive during investigations with a BP level of 60/40 mm Hg and a fall in hemoglobin level. Upper GI bleeding was suspected. Which of the following is considered the investigation of choice in Upper GI bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoscopy Flexible endoscopy is the ‘gold standard investigation of the upper gastrointestinal tract . In upper gastrointestinal bleeding, endoscopy is far superior to any other investigation and offers the possibility of endoscopic therapy. In most circumstances, it is the only investigation required.

Highyeild:

Upper gastrointestinal bleeding is a common medical problem with an incidence of over 100/100,000 per year in Western practice. The incidence of upper gastrointestinal bleeding increases with age, and it is strongly associated with NSAID use. Despite improvements in diagnosis and treatment modalities, in-hospital mortality of 5-10% can still be expected. In patients in whom the cause of bleeding can be found, the most common causes are peptic ulcer, erosions, Mallory-Weiss tear, and bleeding oesophageal varices. The principles of management for upper gastrointestinal bleeding are identical regardless of the cause. The first step is adequate resuscitation followed by an urgent investigation to determine the cause of the bleeding. Intravenous access should be established, and for those with severe bleeding, central venous pressure monitoring should be established , and bladder catheterization performed. Blood transfusion is usually indicated when more than 30% of blood volume has been lost.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Standard ultrasound imaging can be used to investigate the stomach, but used conventionally it is less sensitive than other modalities. Laparoscopic ultrasound is one of the most sensitive methods of detecting liver metastases from gastric cancer. Option: B. Laparoscopy is routine in the assessment of patients with gastric cancer. Its particular value is in the detection of peritoneal disease, which is difficult by any other technique unless the patient has ascites or bulky intraperitoneal deposits. Option: D. Angiography is used most commonly in the investigation of upper gastrointestinal bleeding that is not identified using endoscopy.

Extraedge:

Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy should be carried out by an experienced operator as soon as possible after the patient has been stabilized. In cases of severe bleeding, it should be carried out immediately. The Rockall score can be used to assess the risk of rebleeding and death after upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage. In some patients, bleeding is secondary to a coagulopathy, and the coagulopathy should be corrected, if possible, with fresh-frozen plasma or concentrated clotting factors with hematology advice.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presented with a 2-day history of hematemesis. He reported 25-30 episodes of hematemesis and 5 episodes of melena in the 24 hours before the presentation. He denied abdominal pain, trauma, or ingestion of any sharp or caustic substances. On physical examination, his vital signs were normal, and he had a benign abdominal exam and melena was found in the rectal vault. An esophagogastroduode-noscopy (egd) was urgently performed a 1.5-cm linear tear was found. All of the following statements are true regarding Mallory-Weiss tears except?

options.label: A
options.text: Mallory-Weiss tears occur near the gastroesophageal junction.

options.label: C
options.text: Endoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis.

options.label: D
options.text: Endoscopic therapy with injection or electrocoagulation is effective in all cases

questions.correct_answer: D. Endoscopic therapy with injection or electrocoagulation is effective in all cases
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoscopic therapy with injection or electrocoagulation is effective in all cases Supportive therapy with acid suppression therapy is successful in 90 % of bleeding episodes. In rare cases of severe ongoing bleeding, endoscopic therapy with injection or electrocoagulation may be effective. Angiographic embolization has been successfully employed in cases of failed endoscopic therapy. If all these maneuvers fail, high gastrotomy and suturing of the mucosal tear are indicated.

Highyeild:

Mallory-Weiss tears are partial-thickness tears of the mucosa and submucosa near the gastroesophageal junction. These tears are caused by forceful contraction of the abdominal wall against an unrelaxed cardio, resulting in increased intragastric pressure and mucosal laceration. They were originally associated with alcoholic patients who had a history of intense retching and vomiting following binge drinking, but they can occur in any patient who has a history of repeated vomiting. Mallory-Weiss tears account for 5% to 10% of cases of upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB). Diagnosis is usually made by history, and endoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis. A retroflection maneuver is necessary to view the area just below the gastroesophageal junction to avoid missing this diagnosis in UGIB patients. Most tears occur along the lesser curvature and can extend into the esophagus. Supportive therapy with acid suppression therapy is successful in 90% of bleeding episodes, with the mucosa often healing within 72 hours. In rare cases of severe ongoing bleeding, endoscopic therapy with injection or electrocoagulation may be effective. If these therapies fail, angioembolization with absorbable material such as a gelatin sponge has been successfully employed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Mallory-Weiss tears are partial-thickness tears of the mucosa and submucosa that occur near the gastroesophageal junction. Vigorous vomiting produces a vertical split in the gastric mucosa, immediately below the squamocolumnar junction at the cardia in 90% of cases. Option: B. Classically, mallory-weiss tears develop in alcoholic patients after a period of intense retching and vomiting following binge drinking, but they can occur in any patient who has a history of repeated emesis. Option: C. Mallory-Weiss tears are usually diagnosed by history, and endoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis.

Extraedge:

In cases of failed endoscopic therapy, it is important to rule out variceal bleeding by thoroughly examining the gastroesophageal junction. Recurrent bleeding from a Mallory-Weiss tear is uncommon.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with peptic ulcer disease, suffered from upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage as a result of perforation that led to septic shock. Which of the following tools can be used to assess the in-hospital mortality and length of stay in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aims65 In-hospital mortality and length of stay can be predicted by the aims65 score, with a score of 0 predicting negligible mortality and a score of 5 predicting a 30% in-hospital mortality.

Highyeild:

Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) can lead to complications such as bleeding, perforation, and obstruction, with bleeding being the most common cause of PUD-related deaths in the United States. The AIMS65 score can predict inhospital mortality and length of stay, with a score of 0 indicating negligible mortality and a score of 5 indicating a 30% inhospital mortality. Bleeding peptic ulcers are the most common cause of upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding among hospitalized patients. Symptoms of bleeding peptic ulcers typically include melena and/or hematemesis, while abdominal pain is uncommon. Nasogastric aspiration is often used to confirm upper GI bleeding. Shock may be present in patients with bleeding peptic ulcers, necessitating aggressive resuscitation and blood transfusion.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The forest classification is used to assess the rebleeding risks in peptic ulcer disease based on endoscopic findings. Option: B. The Rockall scoring is used for risk stratification, predicting the outcome and risk of rebleeding. Option: C. Blatchford scoring is used for stratifying the risk and predicting the need for hospital-based intervention in peptic ulcer disease

Extraedge:

AIMS65 takes into account five clinical factors: Albumin level (<3 g/dL) International normalized ratio (INR >1.5) Mental status changes Systolic blood pressure (<90 mmHg) Age (>65 years)

questions.text: An 80-year-old man presented with complaints of "black stools", increasing shortness of breath, chest tightness, and epigastric pain. Initial investigations were found to be normal. Oesophogastroduodenoscopy (old) was scheduled. During the period, the patient's blood pressure dropped to 110/70, pulse increased to 95 and hb decreased to 10.3 g/dl. An upper gastrointestinal bleed was diagnosed and the patient was managed conservatively with aggressive resuscitation and close monitoring. Which of the following is the most common cause of upper gi bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastric ulcer 60% of the upper gi bleeding is attributed to ulcers, out of which 33% is attributed to duodenal ulcer and hence, is the most common cause of upper gi bleed. 21% of upper bleeding is attributed to gastric ulcers and is considered the second commonest cause of upper bleeding.

Highyeild:

Upper gastrointestinal bleeding is a common medical problem with an incidence of over 100/100,000 per year in Western practice. The incidence of upper gastrointestinal bleeding increases with age, and it is strongly associated with NSAID use. Despite improvements in diagnosis and treatment modalities, in-hospital mortality of 5-10% can still be expected. In patients in whom the cause of bleeding can be found, the most common causes are peptic ulcer, erosions, Mallory-Weiss tear, and bleeding oesophageal varices. The principles of management for upper gastrointestinal bleeding are identical regardless of the cause. The first step is adequate resuscitation followed by an urgent investigation to determine the cause of the bleeding. Intravenous access should be established, and for those with severe bleeding, central venous pressure monitoring should be established , and bladder catheterization performed. Blood transfusion is usually indicated when more than 30% of blood volume has been lost.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. 6% of the upper gi bleeding is attributed to oesophageal ulcers. Option: C. 4% of the upper gi bleeding is attributed to oesophageal varices. Option: D. 4% of the upper gi bleeding is attributed to Mallory–Weiss tear.

Extraedge:

The epidemiology of bleeding peptic ulcers is similar to that of perforated ulcers. The population affected by bleeding peptic ulcers has become older in recent years. Bleeding peptic ulcers are commonly associated with the ingestion of NSAIDs. Diagnosis of bleeding peptic ulcers is usually made endoscopically. Occasionally, the nature of the blood loss makes it difficult to identify the lesion accurately.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female with a one-week history of pallor and fatigue. There were no other associated symptoms. She denied diarrhea, melena, hematochezia, and abdominal pain. Physical examination was normal except for a pale appearance. There was abdominal tenderness. Rectal examination revealed tarry black stools. Her medical history was significant for multiple hospitalizations for anemia and transfusions. She was diagnosed with upper gi bleeding through endoscopy. All of the following are indications for surgery in gastrointestinal hemorrhage except?

options.label: A
options.text: Failure of endoscopic techniques to arrest hemorrhage

options.label: B
options.text: Continued slow bleeding with a transfusion requirement exceeding 3 units/day

options.label: C
options.text: Blood transfusion requirement of more than 2 units

questions.correct_answer: C. Blood transfusion requirement of more than 2 units
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Blood transfusion requirement of more than 2 units Ongoing blood transfusion requirement of more than 6 units as an indication for surgical intervention, particularly in the elderly, although an 8- to 10-unit loss may be more acceptable for the younger population.

Highyeild:

Despite advancements in endoscopic therapy, approximately 10% of patients with bleeding ulcers still require surgical intervention for effective hemostasis. The Forrest classification is considered the best predictor of rebleeding in patients with bleeding ulcers. Other endoscopic factors associated with increased risk of rebleeding include active bleeding at the time of endoscopy, large ulcer size (greater than 2 cm), posterior duodenal wall ulcer, and lesser gastric curve ulcer. Clinical judgment and local expertise should play a critical role in the decision-making process for surgical intervention. Indications for surgery for peptic ulcer hemorrhage include ongoing blood transfusion requirements of more than 6 units, the success of endoscopic therapy, and recurrent bleeding after repeat endoscopy. Increased blood transfusions are associated with higher mortality rates . Secondary or relative indications for surgery include rare blood type or difficult crossmatch, refusal of transfusion, shock on presentation, advanced age, severe comorbid disease, and bleeding chronic gastric ulcer with a suspicion of malignancy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Failure of endoscopic techniques to arrest hemorrhage is an indication for surgery in gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Option: B. Continued slow bleeding with a transfusion requirement exceeding 3 units/day hemorrhage is an indication for surgery in gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Option: D. Shock associated with recurrent hemorrhage is an indication for surgery in gastrointestinal hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman developed a cystic artery pseudoaneurysm following an episode of acute cholecystitis. She presented with haematemesis and melaena associated with postural symptoms. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed a duodenal ulcer with adherent clots in the first part of the duodenum. The optimal initial management of a patient hospitalized for a bleeding peptic ulcer is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intravenous ppis All patients are commonly started on either an h2-antagonist or a proton pump antagonist , and recent evidence confirms the benefit of proton pump inhibitor administration to prevent rebleeding after endoscopy in bleeding peptic ulcers. Therapeutic endoscopy can achieve hemostasis in approximately 70% of cases. Long-term maintenance ppi therapy should be considered in all patients admitted to the hospital with ulcer complications. Patients with a visible vessel in the ulcer base, a spurting vessel, or an ulcer with a clot in the base are statistically likely to require surgical treatment to stop the bleeding. A patient who has required more than six units of blood in general needs surgical treatment.

Highyeild:

Medical treatment for bleeding is often limited in effectiveness. Initial treatment typically involves administering an H2 antagonist or a proton pump inhibitor. Recent evidence supports the use of proton pump inhibitors after endoscopy to prevent rebleeding. Tranexamic acid, an inhibitor of fibrinolysis, may reduce overall mortality. Therapeutic endoscopy can achieve hemostasis in about 70% of cases. The most effective treatment involves a combination of adrenaline injection with a heater probe and/or clips. Therapeutic endoscopy may not be effective in patients who are bleeding from large vessels, which is associated with the majority of mortality.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Oversewing alone results in a higher rebleeding rate but a lower operative mortality rate than definitive operation and is most commonly used for bleeding duodenal ulcers. Option: B. Vagotomy and drainage with oversewing and biopsy of the ulcer to rule out cancer is the second best procedure of choice for bleeding gastric ulcer. Option: C. Distal gastric resection to include the bleeding ulcer is the procedure of choice for bleeding gastric ulcer.

Extraedge:

Angiography with transcatheter embolization may be a valuable alternative to surgery in cases where the source of bleeding cannot be identified or if the patient rebleeds after endoscopy. The risk of significant ischemia following embolization is low due to the rich collateral blood supply of the stomach and duodenum. Rescue surgery after failed embolization is associated with poor outcomes, and it may be advantageous to proceed directly to surgery. If bleeding continues, surgical intervention is required except in centers with experience in angiographic embolization, where attempts may be made to arrest bleeding and avoid surgery.

questions.text: A 78-year-old female presents to the emergency room with an acute onset of epigastric pain a couple of hours ago. On physical exam, her abdomen demonstrates significant epigastric tenderness with a rebound. Her pulse is 104, her blood pressure is 80/54 mm hg and her haemoglobin was 4.5 g/dl. She has mild leucocytosis. A peptic ulcer bleeding is suspected in this patient. What is the next step of management in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Resuscitation and risk stratification. Of all the listed options, the immediate step in the management of upper gi bleeding is resuscitation and risk stratification. Large-bore iv access and foley catheterization is accomplished followed by nasogastric intubation.

Highyeild:

Resuscitation and risk stratification are the two primary issues. Large-bore IV access and Foley catheterization are established, and nasogastric intubation may be considered. Risk stratification involves answering several questions related to the extent and severity of the bleeding, the presence of chronic diseases that compromise physiologic reserve, the use of anticoagulants or immunosuppressive drugs, and the findings during endoscopy. Patients judged to be at low risk may stop bleeding with supportive care and intravenous proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) treatment and may be managed on an outpatient basis. High-risk patients require immediate steps, including type and cross-match for transfusion of blood products, admission to the ICU or a specialized unit, consultation with a surgeon and gastroenterologist, initiation of intravenous PPI, and upper endoscopy within 12 hours.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Nasogastric tube insertion with npo status and initiation of iv fluid is a very reasonable step in the modern era of h. Pylori detection and treatment, especially in a stable patient. Option: C. When judged to be low risk, most patients will stop bleeding with supportive treatment and iv ppi. If the patient is deemed to be high risk, the patient is started on intravenous ppi, and upper endoscopy is performed within 12 hours, after resuscitation and correction of coagulopathy. Endoscopic hemostasis should be considered in most high-risk patients with acute upper gi bleeding. Option: D. Anterior seromyotomy is a reasonable approach but not the first option.

Extraedge:

Endoscopic hemostasis should be considered in most high-risk patients with acute upper GI bleeding. Although surgeons should be involved early in the hospital course of high-risk patients, most can be effectively managed without surgery, with endoscopic hemotherapy and medical management.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with no known comorbid illnesses presented with complaints of generalized fatigue, loss of appetite, and unquantified loss of weight for the last 4 months. She was found to be anemic with a hemoglobin of 10 g%. The routine evaluation revealed iron deficiency anemia and stool occult blood was positive. Upper gi endoscopy revealed gastric antral vascular ectasia (given). All of the following statements are true regarding gave except?

options.label: C
options.text: Most patients present with persistent, iron deficiency anemia from continued occult blood loss.

options.label: D
options.text: Endoscopic therapy is indicated for persistent anemia or transfusion-dependent bleeding.

questions.correct_answer: B. Predominantly affects the proximal stomach.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Predominantly affects the proximal stomach. The histologic appearance of gave can resemble portal hypertensive gastropathy which usually affects the proximal stomach, whereas watermelon stomach [GAVE] predominantly affects the distal stomach.

Highyeild:

Gastric antral vascular ectasia ( GAVE ) is named after the parallel red stripes found on the mucosal folds of the distal stomach. Histologically, GAVE is characterized by enlarged blood vessels containing thrombi in the lamina propria, as well as mucosal fibromuscular hyperplasia and hyalinization. GAVE is similar in appearance to portal hypertensive gastropathy, but GAVE is typically found in the distal stomach while portal hypertensive gastropathy usually affects the proximal stomach. Beta-blockers and nitrates are not effective in treating GAVE, which is typically found in elderly women with chronic gastrointestinal blood loss requiring transfusion. GAVE may be associated with an autoimmune connective tissue disorder , and at least a quarter of patients have chronic liver disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Gastric antral vascular ectasia is characterized by a collection of dilated venules that appear as a linear red streak converging on the antrum, giving the appearance of a watermelon and hence the name watermelon stomach. Option: C. Severe hemorrhage is rare in gastric antral vascular ectasia, and most patients present with persistent, iron deficiency anemia from continued occult blood loss. Option: D. Endoscopic therapy is indicated for persistent anemia or transfusion-dependent bleeding. Argon plasma coagulation has a success rate of 90% and is the treatment of choice.

Extraedge:

Treatment options for GAVE include estrogen and progesterone, as well as endoscopic treatment with the neodymium yttrium-aluminum-garnet (Nd: YAG) laser or argon plasma coagulator. If these options are ineffective, an antrectomy may be necessary to control blood loss. However, this operation is more risky for elderly patients. For patients with both portal hypertension and antral vascular ectasia , a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPSS) may be considered.

questions.text: A boy aged 13 years presented with complaints of recurrent episodes of non-bilious, non-projectile vomiting. On clinical examination, vital parameters were normal. The abdomen was diffusely distended with mild epigastric tenderness. An ultrasound scan of the abdomen showed a markedly distended stomach. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy showed mild antral gastritis. The first part of the duodenum was oedematous and a stricture with nodular, ulcerated overlying mucosa was seen. Gastric outlet obstruction due to inflammatory stricture of the duodenum secondary to peptic ulcer disease was considered. Which of the following is considered to be the most common cause of gastric outlet obstruction?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carcinoma of the stomach Gastric cancer is considered to be the most common cause of gastric outlet obstruction . With the decrease in the incidence of peptic ulceration and the advent of potent medical treatments, gastric outlet obstruction should be considered malignant until proven.

Highyeild:

Gastric outlet obstruction is a rare complication of peptic ulcer disease, affecting less than 5% of patients. Duodenal or pre- pyloric ulcers are the usual cause of this obstruction, which can be acute or chronic. Common symptoms include non-bilious vomiting, hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, dehydration, pain or discomfort, and weight loss. A physician may hear a succussion splash by placing a stethoscope in the epigastrium. Initial treatment involves nasogastric suction, intravenous hydration and electrolyte repletion, and acid suppression.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Previously, pyloric stenosis secondary to peptic ulceration was considered to be the most common cause of gastric outlet obstruction. There is a decrease in the incidence of peptic ulceration and with the advent of potent medical treatments, gastric outlet obstruction should be considered malignant until proven. Option: C. Gastric outlet obstruction occurs in no more than 5% of patients with pud. It is usually due to duodenal or prepyloric ulcer disease, and it may be acute (from inflammatory swelling and peristaltic dysfunction) or chronic (from cicatrix). Option: D. Obstruction (the most common complication of crohn's disease) may arise from swelling and the formation of scar tissue. The result is a thickening of the bowel wall and a narrowed intestinal passage. These narrowed areas are called strictures.

Extraedge:

Endoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis, and most patients with obstructing ulcer disease require intervention, such as balloon dilation or surgery. Cancer must be ruled out as a potential cause, as patients with gastric outlet obstruction may have a pancreatic, gastric, or duodenal malignancy .

questions.text: A 76-years-old male patient was complaining of fatigability, dizziness, and occasional black stool for about 6 months. No history of hematemesis or rectal bleeding was noted. Upper endoscopy was reported as mild to moderate gastritis involving the antrum and the distal body and the gastric biopsy from the antrum was reported as mild helicobacter pylori-negative gastritis. Capsule endoscopy showed multiple red punctuate lesions around the pylorus suggestive of gastric antral vascular ectasia (gave). What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Argon plasma coagulator Endoscopic therapy is indicated for persistent anemia or transfusion-dependent bleeding. Argon plasma coagulation has a success rate of 90%. Nonsurgical treatment options for gave include estrogen and progesterone, and endoscopic treatment with the neodymium yttrium-aluminum-garnet (nd:yag) laser or argon plasma coagulator

Highyeild:

Argon plasma coagulator (APC) is used in endoscopy to treat gastrointestinal bleeding disorders. It generates an ionized gas to produce a coagulum that stops bleeding at the site of bleeding. APC is effective and safe in treating gastrointestinal bleeding due to various causes, including gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE). It is a non-surgical treatment option that can be used in combination with other therapies. The decision to use APC in conjunction with other therapies depends on the underlying cause and severity of bleeding.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. β-blockers and nitrates useful in the treatment of portal hypertensive gastropathy are ineffective in patients with gastric antral vascular ectasia. Option: C. Antrectomy may be required to control blood loss, and this operation is quite effective but carries increased morbidity in this elderly patient group. Option: D. Patients with portal hypertension and antral vascular ectasia should be considered for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (tipss).

questions.text: A 73-year-old male presents with a history of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain for 5 weeks. Ct of the abdomen and pelvis revealed new circumferential thickening and inflammatory stranding involving the ascending colon. Diffuse intra- and extra-hepatic biliary ductal and main pancreatic duct dilatation (double duct sign) was noted as well. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen turned out to be negative. The patient was suspected of gastric outlet obstruction. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoscopy The diagnosis of gastric outlet obstruction is confirmed by endoscopy . Flexible endoscopy is more sensitive than conventional radiology in the assessment of the majority of gastroduodenal conditions and is the ‘gold standard investigation of the upper gastrointestinal tract .

Highyeild:

Gastric outlet obstruction is commonly associated with peptic ulcer disease and gastric cancer. Hypochloremic alkalosis is a metabolic abnormality that is usually only seen in patients with peptic ulcer disease and should be treated with isotonic saline with potassium. Endoscopic biopsy is essential to exclude malignancy in cases of gastric outlet obstruction. Aggressive medical therapy for peptic ulcer disease often leads to the resolution of gastric outlet obstruction. Endoscopic dilation of the gastric outlet may be effective in treating benign stenosis. Surgery is frequently required for gastric outlet obstruction caused by malignancy. For benign disease, a drainage procedure is usually performed, while appropriate resection is done for malignancy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Angiography is used most commonly in the investigation of upper gastrointestinal bleeding that is not identified using endoscopy. Option: B. Standard ultrasound imaging can be used to investigate the stomach, but used conventionally it is less sensitive than other modalities. Option: C. Magnetic resonance imaging (mri) scanning does not offer any specific advantage in assessing the stomach, although it has a higher sensitivity for the detection of gastric cancer liver metastases than conventional ct imaging.

questions.text: A 50- year male presented with complaints of severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for 2 days, a weakness for 5 months, has passed stool 2 days ago, and weight loss for 2 months. All routine laboratory tests were within normal range except, for decreased hemoglobin level, increase in white blood cells also increased creatinine level, and decreased albumin level. In abdominal ultrasonography, it was mentioned that severely edematous mucosa with erosive patches and places, pyloric canal deformed scope could not be negotiated across the pylorus. Barium meal study depicted dilated stomach where greater curvature is below the level of the iliac crest. The patient was diagnosed with gastric outlet obstruction due to peptic ulcer disease. What is the first line of management in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Correction of acid-base balance The first step in the treatment of gastric outlet obstruction involves correcting the metabolic abnormality. The patient should be rehydrated with intravenous isotonic saline with potassium supplementation. Replacing the sodium chloride and water allows the kidney to correct the acid–base abnormality. It is notable that the metabolic abnormalities may be less if the obstruction is due to malignancy, as the acid–base disturbance is less pronounced.

Highyeild:

Primary objective: Treat mechanical obstruction and metabolic abnormalities simultaneously Rehydration with intravenous isotonic saline and potassium supplementation to correct metabolic abnormalities Restores acid-base balance and supports kidney function Acid-base disturbance may be less pronounced if obstruction due to malignancy Emptying stomach necessary for endoscopy and contrast radiology Large nasogastric tube may not be sufficient, orogastric tube and lavage may be necessary Biopsy of the area around pylorus essential to exclude malignancy Conservative treatment may be effective in early cases

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Traditionally, severe cases of gastric outlet obstruction are treated surgically, usually with a gastroenterostomy rather than a pyloroplasty. Option: C. Endoscopic treatment with balloon dilatation has been practised and maybe most useful in early cases. Option: D. Early cases may settle with conservative treatment, presumably as edema around the ulcer diminishes as the ulcer is healed. Traditionally, severe cases of gastric outlet obstruction are treated surgically, usually with a gastroenterostomy rather than a pyloroplasty. Severe cases traditionally treated surgically with gastroenterostomy Endoscopic treatment with balloon dilatation may be useful in early cases and may need to be repeated. Duodenal stent insertion may be considered in patients with unresectable malignancy.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented to the hospital with very severe lower abdominal pain. The pain was non-radiating and associated with vomiting, haematemesis, and Malena. On examination, he appeared flushed, with lower abdominal tenderness and peritonism that was markedly worse over the left iliac fossa. The Stool was found to be black and sticky. His heart rate was 140 bpm, blood pressure was 90/70 mm hg and respiratory rate was 20 bpm. Endoscopy revealed an upper gi bleed in the first part of the duodenum. A diagnosis of bleeding duodenal ulcer was made. Which is the most common site for erosion of a bleeding duodenal ulcer?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastroduodenal artery Duodenal ulceration most commonly occurs in the first part of the duodenum. The gastroduodenal artery, which is also a branch of the hepatic artery, passes behind the first part of the duodenum, highly relevant with respect to the bleeding duodenal ulcer. Anteriorly placed ulcers tend to perforate and, in contrast, posterior duodenal ulcers tend to bleed.

Highyeild:

The most common site for the erosion of a bleeding duodenal ulcer is the posterior wall of the duodenal bulb. The duodenal bulb is the first part of the duodenum. The gastroduodenal artery passes behind the first part of the duodenum. If a duodenal ulcer erodes through the posterior wall of the duodenal bulb, it can cause a bleed from the gastroduodenal artery. This can lead to upper gastrointestinal bleeding , which is a medical emergency that requires prompt evaluation and treatment. Duodenal ulcers can also occur in other parts of the duodenum, such as the second and third portions, but erosion in these areas is less common than erosion in the posterior wall of the duodenal bulb.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. The fundus of the stomach is supplied by the vasa brevia (or short gastric arteries) and is not the common site for the erosion of a bleeding duodenal ulcer. Option: C. Large chronic gastric ulcers may erode posteriorly into the pancreas and, on other occasions, into major vessels such as the splenic artery. Option: D. On the lesser curve, the left gastric artery, a branch of the coeliac axis, forms an anastomotic arcade with the right gastric artery, which arises from the common hepatic artery and is not the common site for the erosion of a bleeding duodenal ulcer.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of hematemesis for 2 h and the volume was over 1000 ml. He also had palpitations, fatigue, and sweating. On examination, the temperature was 36.4 °c, blood pressure was 80/50 mmhg, and heart rate was 135 bpm. Laboratory data showed routine blood tests: hemoglobin 72 g/l, white blood cells 13.41 × 109/l, total platelets 60 × 109; c-reactive protein 159.90 mg/l; blood gas analysis: oxygen partial pressure 79.3 mmHg, co2 partial pressure 30.8 mmHg, ph value 7.281; and normal liver and renal function and coagulation tests. Gi haemorrhage was considered and the site of bleeding was not identified on endoscopy. Which of the following investigation will you consider to find the source of upper gi bleeding in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Angiography Angiography is used most commonly in the investigation of upper gastrointestinal bleeding that is not identified using endoscopy.

Highyeild:

Angiography is commonly used in the investigation of upper gastrointestinal bleeding when endoscopy fails to identify the source of bleeding. This procedure involves injecting a contrast dye into the arteries that supply blood to the gastrointestinal tract , followed by X-ray imaging to identify the source of bleeding. Therapeutic embolization is a minimally invasive procedure that involves injecting a substance into the blood vessels to block the blood flow to the bleeding site. Embolization may be used as an alternative to surgery in some cases and can be effective in stopping bleeding. Some centers have replaced surgery with embolization as the preferred treatment for upper gastrointestinal bleeding in the majority of cases. The decision to use embolization or surgery will depend on various factors, such as the location and severity of the bleeding, the patient's overall health, and the expertise of the medical team.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Standard ultrasound imaging can be used to investigate the stomach, but used conventionally it is less sensitive than other modalities. Laparoscopic ultrasound is one of the most sensitive methods of detecting liver metastases from gastric cancer. Option: B. Laparoscopy is routine in the assessment of patients with gastric cancer. Its particular value is in the detection of peritoneal disease, which is difficult by any other technique unless the patient has ascites or bulky intraperitoneal deposits. Option: C. Flexible endoscopy is the ‘gold standard investigation of the upper gastrointestinal tract. In upper gastrointestinal bleeding, endoscopy is far superior to any other investigation and offers the possibility of endoscopic therapy. In most circumstances it is the only, investigation required.

Extraedge:

Angiography carries some risks , including bleeding at the catheter insertion site, allergic reactions to the contrast dye, and damage to blood vessels. However, these risks are generally low and can be minimized with careful monitoring and appropriate management.

questions.text: Find out the true statement regarding the clinical condition shown in image?

options.label: B
options.text: Can be expected if erythema appears that changes color on pressure

questions.correct_answer: D. Vacuum dressings can be effective
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vacuum dressings can be effective Explanation for correct answer: The image shown is a bed sore. Vacuum dressings, rotations flaps can be effective in bed sores. A bedsore is a gangrene caused by local pressure.

Highyeild:

Vacuum dressings and rotational flaps are treatments for pressure ulcers, also known as bed sores. Bed sores are caused by prolonged pressure on the skin and underlying tissues, which can lead to tissue damage and necrosis. Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) dressings involve applying negative pressure to the wound through a specialized dressing, which helps to remove excess fluid and promote healing by increasing blood flow and oxygenation to the affected area. Rotational flaps involve surgically moving healthy tissue from a nearby area to cover the ulcer, which can help to promote healing and prevent further tissue damage. The best treatment for pressure ulcers depends on the severity and stage of the ulcer, as well as the overall health of the patient. Other treatments for pressure ulcers may include repositioning the patient, keeping the wound clean and moist, and managing underlying medical conditions that may contribute to the development of pressure ulcers.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. This is false. Bedsores are predisposed by 5 factors : pressure, injury, anaemia, malnutrition, moisture. Option: B. This is false. Bedsores can be expected if erythema appears that does not change colour on pressure. Option: C. This is false. Bedsores are difficult to heal.

Extraedge:

Vacuum-assisted closure ( VAC ) dressings have been shown to be effective in promoting wound healing and reducing the risk of infection in patients with pressure ulcers. Rotational flaps are typically used for more severe pressure ulcers that do not respond to other treatments, and may require specialized surgical expertise.
